awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Interdisciplinary Research Training Across Biology, Physics, and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Yale University, located in New Haven, CT, will support the training of 9 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2018-2020. The REU Site focuses on several interdisciplinary research areas, including: A) the physical properties of cellular processes, B) the development of new experimental methods at the interface of physics, engineering, and biology, C) molecular engineering, and D) systems biology. By conducting research in one of these focus areas, and being exposed to the other three, participants will gain a deeper understanding of how interdisciplinary research is conducted and how wet-lab experiments, computer simulations, and theory are combined to make rapid progress in answering grand challenges in biology. Participants will receive mentorship from REU faculty, as well as graduate students and postdocs. In addition to conducting interdisciplinary research in Yale laboratories, undergraduates will also participate in a variety of enrichment activities, such as workships aimed at identifying ethical conflicts faced by scientists and at clarifying the PhD admissions process. This REU Site seeks students with majors in several disciplines, including but not limited to biology, biochemistry, computer science, biomedical engineering, physics, and mathematics.

It is anticipated that a total of 27 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Participants will develop their communication skills and will present their research to a wide range of audiences, learning valuable networking skills, and also participating in science outreach activities to middle and high school students. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of this training program. Students will be tracked after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about this REU Site program is available by visiting https://sackler.yale.edu/sackler-nsf-reu-site, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Corey O?Hern at corey.ohern@yale.edu) or the program administrator (Dr. Dorottya Noble at dorottya.noble@yale.edu). This award is supported by the Directorate for Biological Sciences (DBI Division) and the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The NSF REU Site: “Interdisciplinary Research Training Across Biology, Physics, and Engineering” provided hands-on research experiences for 10 weeks during the summer for undergraduates interested in pursuing graduate studies in science and engineering and careers in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM).  The program was run in-person in 2018 and 2019, but virtually in 2020 and 2021 because of COVID-19. All program participants received mentoring from faculty members, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers, as well as REU program staff, as they perfomed  high-impact, cutting-edge research at the interface of biology, physics and engineering.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Undergraduate participants entered our NSF REU Site with a variety of majors, including physics and biophysics, biology, biochemistry, neuroscience, biomedical engineering, mechanical engineering, and mathematics. The REU program focused on helping students to understand how quantitative approaches and tools from physics and engineering are used to advance biological research. In addition to conducting research in a participating research laboratory, they also learned about the research that other participants conducted in other laboratories at Yale. The four specific research areas of the NSF REU Site were: A) Physical properties of cellular processes, B) Development of new experimental methods at the interface of physics, engineering, and biology, C) Molecular engineering, and D) Systems biology. The REU participants conducted research in one of these four research areas, focusing on how theoretical and computational research is combined with wet-lab experiments and the challenges scientists face when conducting interdisciplinary research. The mentorship received in the laboratories also helped participants learn how to plan and develop experiments, and analyze and display data. Additionally, exposure to a broad range of research topics helped participants decide what area of research they are most interested in pursuing and whether they should pursue graduate studies in STEM disciplines. During the project period, five manuscripts with REU participants as co-authors have been published.

 

 

Broader Impacts:

A total of 30 undergraduates (15 (50%) from underrepresented groups and 6 (20%) rising sophomores) participated in the program over the four-year project period, most coming from four-year institutions without STEM Ph.D. programs and often without access to state-of-the-art equipment present at large research institutions. Professional development skills were developed through participating in program-related activities and workshops that focused on improving science communication to interdisciplinary and lay audiences, becoming more aware of STEM career options, and learning about the graduate school application process. REU students also learned about ethical conflicts that scientists face and had many opportunities to network with researchers within the Yale community. Of the 30 participants, 15 (50%) are still pursuing their Bachelor’s degrees, 10 (33%) are applying to Ph.D. programs or pursuing a Ph.D., 1 (3%) is enrolled in a Masters of Public Health program and later pursuing an M.D. or dual-degree program, 3 (10%) are in a STEM job, and 1 (3%) is unknown. This NSF REU Site has contributed to the growth and diversification of the STEM workforce.
